    <item>
      <title>Rita Ora quits X Factor after one season</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/10/rita-ora-quits-x-factor-simon-cowell-cheryl-fernandez-versini</link>
      <description><p>Simon Cowell is now the only judge remaining from last year’s lineup after Cheryl Fernandez-Versini and Nick Grimshaw exit<br></p><p>Rita Ora has quit The X Factor after appearing for just one season.</p><p>With both <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/apr/05/cheryl-fernandez-versini-quits-as-x-factor-judge">Cheryl Fernandez-Versini</a> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/feb/19/nick-grimshaw-x-factor-radio-1-caroline-flack">Nick Grimshaw</a> having left the ITV talent show, the only judge now remaining from the 2015 lineup is Simon Cowell.</p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">I had a ball on <a href="https://twitter.com/TheXFactor">@TheXFactor</a> last year and will miss the team.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/apr/05/simon-cowell-bbc-countryfile-bgt-x-factor-britains-got-talent">Simon Cowell praises BBC's Countryfile, but says BGT is 'biggest show on planet'</a> </p><p lang="en" dir="ltr"><a href="https://twitter.com/SimonCowell">@simoncowell</a> can't wait to work with you again... I'll be round for dinner soon. Thank you for the experience &amp; love X</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/mar/29/dermot-oleary-x-factor-simon-cowell">Dermot O’Leary to return to The X Factor after a year away</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/10/rita-ora-quits-x-factor-simon-cowell-cheryl-fernandez-versini">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Inside the bootcamps where YouTube grows its next generation of stars</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/06/how-youtube-makes-its-next-generation-stars</link>
      <description><p>What is it like to be a NextUp contest winner, one of 16 hopefuls chosen as emerging stars by YouTube and trained to be the next PewDiePie or Zoella</p><p>“If people are learning about John Stuart Mill and what he thought about utilitarianism, that’s fine. Nobody really gets angry about that. But if you’re talking about critical gender theory, or critical race theory or feminism or transphobia, that’s when people get a lot more touchy … ”</p><p>Olly Lennard may not be your idea of an average YouTuber. Rather than playing games or giving makeup tips, his channel dishes out the syllabus from his masters degree in philosophy, one 5-10 minute video at a time.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/apr/28/children-toys-unboxing-channels-youtube-real-stars">How toy unboxing channels became YouTube's real stars</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/apr/09/youtubers-hit-mainstream-digital-media-top-choice-new-talent">YouTubers hit mainstream as digital media become top choice for new talent</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/mar/25/kids-minecraft-youtube-videos-stampy-diamond-minecart">Your kids want to make Minecraft YouTube videos – but should you let them?</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/feb/03/why-youtube-stars-popular-zoella">Why are YouTube stars so popular?</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/06/how-youtube-makes-its-next-generation-stars">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Michael McIntyre makes solid BBC1 debut as BGT soars to more than 10m</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/apr/18/michael-mcintyre-bbc1-bgt-bang-on-the-money-simon-cowell</link>
      <description><p>Comedian’s new variety show beats ITV gameshow Bang on the Money, but the night is dominated by Simon Cowell contest<br></p><p>The debut of Michael McIntyre’s Big Show on BBC1 on Saturday pulled in 4.8 million viewers for the BBC, comfortably beating ITV’s new family gameshow Bang on the Money. </p><p>The 4.8 million audience for McIntyre’s new series was slightly more than the 4.5 million who tuned into to the final episode of The Voice, which is moving to ITV from next year. It was comfortably ahead of the average of 3.2 million who watched Bang on the Money, which is fronted by DJs Rickie and Melvin.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/apr/17/tv-drama-netflix-entertainment">TV is packed with drama as hunt for the Next Big Thing goes on</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/apr/18/michael-mcintyre-bbc1-bgt-bang-on-the-money-simon-cowell">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>TV is packed with drama as hunt for the Next Big Thing goes on</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/apr/17/tv-drama-netflix-entertainment</link>
      <description>Cash-strapped broadcasters under pressure from Netflix have turned to safe fare – but where are the new entertainment hits?<p>Is Saturday night television ever going to be all right again? The final of The Voice this year suffered its lowest ratings ever, having lost almost a third of the 6.3 million viewers who watched in 2015. To be fair, the BBC1 show had to compete with the launch of ITV best performer Britain’s Got Talent, which took a 40.3% share of all TV viewing in its primetime Saturday night slot. Yet, although 8.8 million of us tuned in to watch a man almost impale himself on a swallowed sword, that was 1.3 million fewer than watched in 2015.</p><p>Netflix, the streaming juggernaut with 75 million subscribers worldwide, said last week that it was looking <a href="http://viewer.gutools.co.uk/preview/media/2016/apr/12/x-factor-tv-competitions-netflix-the-crown" title="">to reinvent entertainment formats</a>. First up should be a show for television executives called The Hunt for a New Format. The prize could be an unscripted hit for the next generation, unveiled on a Saturday night to a television scheduler weeping with relief and joy.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/apr/17/tv-drama-netflix-entertainment">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>No direction: have boybands hit the end of the road?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/14/one-direction-boybands-jls-x-factor-stereo-kicks</link>
      <description><p>With One Direction on hiatus and the latest manufactured outfits tanking, the future looks bleak for pop’s permabuffed princelings. Perhaps it’s time to bring back the dance routine …</p><p>During the 11th series of the UK <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/the-x-factor">X Factor</a> in 2014, a tried and tested formula was being played out with thudding familiarity. Eight similarly bequiffed teenage mannequins called things like Barclay, Reese and Casey – each one having been dumped out of the competition – were told their dreams had been reignited and they were being thrown together to form pop’s most ludicrous boyband, Stereo Kicks. A decade or so earlier and this idea of creating a two-for-the-price-of-one boyband would have seemed borderline genius, and yet they finished fifth, were ignored by Syco and disbanded three months after their debut single peaked at No 31. It’s part of a wider trend. Since the heyday of the 90s, each 16-legged experiment like Stereo Kicks, or lads-on-tour urchins the Wanted, or anti-movement balladeers Westlife, has slowly chipped away at the wonderfully choreographed and gloriously uncool legacy created by the Backstreet Boys, N’Sync and Take That. So where next for the boyband?</p><p>The distant death knell started clanging last year when <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/aug/25/one-direction-three-members-say-break-not-permanent">One Direction</a> – by far the most successful boyband since the Backstreet Boys – announced a (possibly permanent) hiatus. In their wake they’d left a new variation on the formula – one that favoured skinny jeans over loose, billowy and shiny trousers, floral shirts over deep-V T-shirts and designer stubble where an ostentatious goatee used to be. Suddenly, dancing in unison was verboten and matching outfits were seen as naff (which, let’s be honest, they are, but no more naff then being dressed up like River Island employees).</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/14/one-direction-boybands-jls-x-factor-stereo-kicks">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Saturday's best TV: Britain's Got Talent; Kelly Holmes: My Marathon Story; The Voice final</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/apr/09/saturdays-best-tv-britains-got-talent-kelly-holmes-my-marathon-story-the-voice-final</link>
      <description><p>ITV’s talent search returns, the middle-distance athlete is in conversation with Paula Radcliffe, and there’s a record deal to be won in the final of The Voice</p><p><strong>7pm, ITV</strong><br>On April Fools’ Day, rumours abounded that this new series of ITV’s talent search would see rejects exit via a trapdoor. While the idea of Simon and co sending a 12-year-old and her puppy plummeting through a stage might seem sadistic, at least it would have added a touch of intrigue to a format which, 10 series in, is as predictable as David Walliams’s innuendos. Yet you can always rely on BGT, with its contortionists and puppetry, for the kind of gentle fun that makes the likes of The X Factor look hollow in comparison. <em>Hannah J Davies</em></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/apr/09/saturdays-best-tv-britains-got-talent-kelly-holmes-my-marathon-story-the-voice-final">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>BBC looks to US to inspire next Saturday night hit</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/apr/08/bbc1-ratings-war-the-voice-final-prized-apart-tumble</link>
      <description><p>Broadcaster seeks to fill hole left by The Voice, as Britain’s Got Talent returns to ITV</p><p>The BBC will look to the success of James Corden’s Carpool Karaoke as inspiration for its next generation of entertainment hits when <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/the-voice">The Voice</a> comes to an end on BBC1.<br></p><p>BBC1 faces losing out in the Saturday night ratings war after the final instalment of The Voice this weekend, with Simon Cowell’s Britain’s Got Talent returning to ITV and Strictly Come Dancing not back until the autumn.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/culture/2016/apr/01/james-corden-carpool-karaoke-viral-videos-adele-justin-bieber">James Corden’s Carpool Karaoke: what makes this late-night viral hit so good?</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/apr/08/bbc1-ratings-war-the-voice-final-prized-apart-tumble">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/media/bbc1">BBC1</category>

      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/tv-and-radio">Television & radio</category>

      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/media/media">Media</category>

    <item>
      <title>Surely, finally, this is the end for The X Factor</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/apr/06/surely-finally-this-is-the-end-for-the-x-factor</link>
      <description><p>Cheryl’s left, Louis Walsh is threatening to return – and even if the show does by some miracle survive, it will have to compete with The Voice. Will someone put The X Factor out of its misery? </p><p>You have to feel sorry for <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/the-x-factor">The X Factor</a> at this point. Right now, it’s the fool in a barrel frantically trying to paddle away from Niagara Falls. It’s the spider in the bathtub that hasn’t noticed the taps being turned on. It’s the broken-ribbed corpse the crying doctor won’t stop pounding. By all indications, this is the end for The X Factor.</p><p>Admittedly, it’s managed to run on fumes for longer than anyone could have guessed. Looking back, the rot set in when <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/simoncowell">Simon Cowell</a> ran off to conquer America and left Gary Barlow the dismal fun-sponge in charge. That was five years ago, but The X Factor is somehow still clinging on. Yet all the signs are currently pointing to The X Factor’s imminent death. Just take a look.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/apr/06/surely-finally-this-is-the-end-for-the-x-factor">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Share your tributes and memories of Ronnie Corbett</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2016/mar/31/share-your-tributes-and-memories-of-comedian-ronnie-corbett</link>
      <description><p>We’d like to hear your tributes to an entertainer and comedian whose work transcended generations</p><p>Ronnie Corbett, one of Britain’s most popular entertainers, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/mar/31/ronnie-corbett-dies-aged-85">has died aged 85 surrounded by his family</a>.</p><p>Corbett was a staple of British television for more than 50 years and will be particularly remembered for his rambling monologues which went off at wild tangents on The Two Ronnies.</p><p>In our business you have to have your armoury ready before the chance of a break. You’ve got to be able to sing a bit, dance a bit, perhaps play the piano and remember lines. If someone says, ‘We’ve got a job for you’, you don’t want to say, ‘Bugger, I can’t do that.’ You have to be prepared.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2016/mar/31/share-your-tributes-and-memories-of-comedian-ronnie-corbett">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Run, Dermot! Run while you still can! Dermot O'Leary returns to X Factor</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/mar/29/dermot-oleary-returns-to-x-factor-run-dermot-run-while-you-still-can-</link>
      <description><p>Simon Cowell has published a cheery, if creepy, press release heralding the presenter’s comeback. But O’Leary would do well to stay away</p><p>“Dermot’s back! Hooray! And so is his dancing! Welcome home, Dermot.”</p><p>That’s a quote by Simon Cowell, heralding Dermot O’Leary’s return to The X Factor. Because, yes, Dermot O’Leary is returning to The X Factor. He didn’t host last year and, in his absence, the show became a weird ham-fisted parody of itself. Watching the last series of The X Factor was like watching the sort of horrific Lithuanian variety show that Clive James would disbelievingly introduce in 1982, where everyone’s drunk and perpetually on the verge of tears. It was like watching the end of civilisation itself.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/mar/29/dermot-oleary-x-factor-simon-cowell">Dermot O’Leary to return to The X Factor after a year away</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/mar/29/dermot-oleary-returns-to-x-factor-run-dermot-run-while-you-still-can-">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Paul Daniels dies aged 77 – video report</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/video/2016/mar/17/paul-daniels-dies-aged-77-video-report</link>
      <description><p>Magician Paul Daniels has died aged 77, after being diagnosed with a brain tumour. He was at his Berkshire home with wife Debbie McGee when he died early on Thursday. Daniels was born Newton Edward Daniels in Middlesbrough and developed his magic skills in working men’s clubs, making his TV debut on talent series Opportunity Knocks. He is best known for the BBC’s Paul Daniels Magic Show which lasted for 15 years</p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/mar/17/paul-daniels-tv-magician-dies-aged-77">Paul Daniels, TV magician, dies aged 77</a><br></li></ul> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/video/2016/mar/17/paul-daniels-dies-aged-77-video-report">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Other magicians did tricks – Paul Daniels performed magic | Peter Ormerod</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/mar/17/paul-daniels-magic-national-treasure</link>
      <description><p>He was a virtuoso of his art, eliciting wonder and amazement. But the national treasure status he so richly deserved somehow eluded him</p><p>In the end, perhaps his greatest feat was convincing us he didn’t matter as much as he did. <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/stage/2016/mar/17/paul-daniels-obituary" title="">Paul Daniels</a> always had an uncertain grasp of his own importance: it’s hard to reconcile the magician depicted in his markedly immodest autobiography with the youth who suffered from an inferiority complex. In his last years, he appeared determined to rubbish what remained of his mystique: his “first farewell tour” was named From Legend to Leg End, while the home page of his website until recently described him as a “sex symbol and bodybuilder”.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/stage/2016/mar/17/paul-daniels-obituary">Paul Daniels obituary</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/stage/2015/nov/25/magic-shows-cast-spell-over-west-end-london">Magic shows cast spell over London's West End</a> </p><p>My hope is that, as Daniels looked back on his career in his last days, he could see his brilliance for what it was</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/mar/17/paul-daniels-magic-national-treasure">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Clinton tweets upcoming clip with an offer to the women behind America’s favourite stoner comedy: ‘You’re welcome at (the real) HQ any time’</p><p>Presidential hopeful Hillary Clinton has taken a bold step towards the millennial vote, joining Abbi Jacobson and Ilana Glazer in Comedy Central’s hit TV series Broad City.<br tabindex="-1"></p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/tvandradioblog/2014/apr/14/broad-city-comedy-genius">The genius of Broad City: at last, a comedy that speaks to my world</a> </p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">You’re welcome at (the real) HQ any time, <a href="https://twitter.com/broadcity">@BroadCity</a>.<a href="https://t.co/BQIFqxoTQV">https://t.co/BQIFqxoTQV</a></p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">On the set of <a href="https://twitter.com/broadcity">@broadcity</a> season 3 with <a href="https://twitter.com/abbijacobson">@abbijacobson</a>, <a href="https://twitter.com/ilazer">@ilazer</a> and Amy! <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/yas?src=hash">#yas</a> <a href="https://t.co/KYOAWDSshK">pic.twitter.com/KYOAWDSshK</a></p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Just three best friends on the set of <a href="https://twitter.com/broadcity">@BroadCity</a> season 3! <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/Hillary2016?src=hash">#Hillary2016</a> ♥️ <a href="https://twitter.com/HillaryClinton">@HillaryClinton</a> <a href="https://t.co/cHQD58Idjd">pic.twitter.com/cHQD58Idjd</a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/mar/16/hillary-clinton-meets-ilana-and-abbi-in-new-broad-city-clip">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>How we made The Tube</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2016/mar/15/how-we-made-the-tube-80s-tv-pop-show</link>
      <description><p>Jools Holland: ‘When Rik Mayall vomited into a camera, one man in Northampton was so appalled he called the police.’</p><p>Tyne Tees Television were looking for presenters for this new pop show. I did my <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bXUWTQkmOos">audition with Paula Yates</a> and it was chaotic. Paula interviewed a youth and ended up getting so cross she tried to slap him. I interviewed someone who was supposed to be dead and dragged him across the floor. The TV people said that we were hopeless but that they couldn’t stop watching us.</p><p>After filming we all stayed in the same Newcastle hotel. Ian Dury, Chaka Khan... it was full-on</p><p>Jarvis Cocker was driven to the audition by his mum.       <title>Keeping Australia Alive: no second takes in ABC's ambitious medical show</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/mar/12/keeping-australia-alive-no-second-takes-in-abcs-ambitious-medical-show</link>
      <description><p>Cash-strapped broadcaster’s new reality series reveals intimate footage of patients’ lives captured in 24-hour period</p><p>We’ve seen a lot of Australian hospital reality shows over the years. The standard bearer was Channel Nine’s RPA, which ran from 1995 to 2012 and followed a patient’s medical journey from the moment they entered Royal Prince Alfred hospital in Sydney. On air now is Kings Cross ER: St Vincent’s Hospital, also on Nine, a faster-paced medical show packed with drugs and stabbings, and Medical Emergency, on Channel Seven, which is set in Melbourne’s Alfred hospital’s trauma unit.</p><p>So why would the cash-strapped ABC mount an ambitious, seven-hour series filmed in a single day in multiple locations across Australia?</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/mar/03/the-family-review-abc-joan-allen-andrew-mccarthy-room-the-imposter">The Family: ABC's buzzed about thriller is an intriguing but generic imposter</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/feb/27/hospital-people-review-last-nights-tv-mockumentary-tom-binns">Hospital People review – a medical mock doc that's all in a muddle</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/mar/12/keeping-australia-alive-no-second-takes-in-abcs-ambitious-medical-show">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/mar/04/x-factor-winner-dami-im-to-represent-australia-at-2016-eurovision-song-contest</link>
      <description><p>Korean-born Australian singer’s performance in Stockholm in May will be the second time Australia has competed in the song contest </p><p>Dami Im says being chosen as Australia’s 2016 Eurovision entry is the biggest thing to happen in her career.<br></p><p>The X Factor winner, who will perform in Stockholm in May, was announced on Thursday evening as the European song contest’s Australian entry.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2015/may/24/guy-sebastian-australia-eurovision-fifth-place">Guy Sebastian carries Australia's high Eurovision hopes to a heady fifth place</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2015/nov/17/australia-compete-eurovision-again-next-year">Australia to compete in Eurovision again in 2016</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/mar/04/x-factor-winner-dami-im-to-represent-australia-at-2016-eurovision-song-contest">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Liam Payne fuels rumours of romance with Cheryl Fernandez-Versini</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/feb/28/liam-payne-one-direction-xfactor-cheryl-instagram</link>
      <description><p>One Direction star ‘confirms’ reports of alleged relationship with X Factor judge by posting picture of them together<br></p><p>It’s the perfect coming-of-age tale for the Pop Idol generation. Liam Payne, the once baby-faced member of One Direction, is reportedly in a “blooming” relationship with Cheryl Fernandez-Versini, the singer who, five years ago, sat on the X Factor judging panel that catapulted him and his boyband to global stardom. </p><p>The romance seems to be the latest instalment of One Direction’s “boys to men” saga, kickstarted by Zayn Malik’s departure from the group last year to make music videos featuring more tastefully naked flesh than Simon Cowell ever allowed and closely followed by the revelation of Louis Tomlinson’s lovechild. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/feb/28/liam-payne-one-direction-xfactor-cheryl-instagram">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Atmosphere of fear still exists at BBC, Savile abuse report concludes</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/feb/25/jimmy-savile-abuse-bbc-culture-damned</link>
      <description><p>Dame Janet Smith inquiry involving nearly 500 witnesses for Savile and Stuart Hall sexual abuse says culture at corporation made it difficult to ‘rock the boat’</p><p>After three-and-a-half years, hundreds of interviews and an outlay of millions of pounds, on Thursday Dame Janet Smith published her report on the culture of the BBC during the Jimmy Savile and Stuart Hall era.</p><p>The former court of appeal judge and her team spoke to more than 380 witnesses for the Savile investigation, 117 of whom had worked at the BBC. Dame Linda Dobbs also spoke to more than 100 witnesses for the Hall inquiries. The final combined report runs to 372,400 words.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/feb/25/report-savile-abuse-bbc-published-inquiry-launch">Savile BBC abuse report to be published over three years after inquiry launch</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/feb/24/jimmy-savile-victims-nspcc-report">Jimmy Savile victims laughed at, says NSPCC report</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/feb/25/stuart-hall-victim-felt-intimidated-giving-evidence-to-bbc-inquiry">Stuart Hall victim felt 'intimidated' giving evidence to BBC inquiry</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/feb/25/jimmy-savile-abuse-bbc-culture-damned">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Paul Daniels, magician and entertainer, diagnosed with incurable cancer</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/feb/20/paul-daniels-magician-and-entertainer-diagnosed-with-incurable-tumour</link>
      <description><p>Family statement confirms that Daniels, famed for his television series on BBC from 1979 to 1994, has inoperable brain tumour</p><p>The magician and entertainer Paul Daniels, 77, has incurable cancer, his family have said. “We can confirm that one of our greatest magicians and entertainers of all times, Paul Daniels, has sadly been diagnosed with an incurable brain tumour,” a statement from Daniels’ publicist said.<br></p><p>“On behalf of Paul, Debbie and their families, we thank you for your kind concerns and support at this sad time and ask that their privacy continues to be respected. There will be no further comments at this time.” <br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/feb/20/paul-daniels-magician-and-entertainer-diagnosed-with-incurable-tumour">Continue reading...</a></description>
